Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Multiphase flow physics driving respiratory infectious disease transmission

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: The current COVID-19 coronavirus outbreak vividly demonstrates the acute global danger emanating from a local event in a hyperconnected world. A key public health challenge is the immediate reduction in host-to-host transmission events, particularly in front-line healthcare workers taking direct care of COVID-19 patients. Such patients often have to undergo medical procedures that induce respiratory emissions and thereby put healthcare workers at risk. This RAPID project aims to reduce the host-to-host transmission of COVID-19 during such “aerosol” emission-producing medical procedures by developing, testing, and deploying fluid-dynamics-based solutions at the patient’s bedside that can essentially syphon off the emissions coming from a patient and protect healthcare workers and other personnel.<br/><br/>This RAPID project seeks to develop such non-pharmacologic containment approaches by first visualizing and quantifying the multiphase nature of respiratory emissions during exhalations, coughs, and aerosol-generating medical procedures pertinent to COVID-19 patients. Based on that quantification, the project will model and quantify the impact of locally applied multiphase flow control for containing, diverting, and collecting the pathogen-laden emissions from the patient and thus reduce exposure to healthcare providers. Finally, the project will develop rapid prototype systems for deployment at the patient’s bedside in clinically relevant settings. The benefits of the project to healthcare professionals and the public rest with the rapid development of concrete and actionable non-pharmacological interventions to curb host-to-host transmission of respiratory infectious diseases and in particular protection of healthcare workers at the frontline of this historic pandemic.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Non-pharmacological infection control strategies and modelling and risk assessment of respiratory pathogen transmission that accounts for indoor air and environmental conditions  have become of paramount importance when considering the built environment, especially in high-occupancy settings (hospitals, schools, universities, office buildings, mass transportation). This includes improving fundamental innovation and quantification of material filtration efficiency for the rational design of personal protective equipment, air filtration systems, and other flow diversion approaches to reduce the risk of inhalation of pathogen-laden droplets. In this work we have studies a range of emissions and mitigations strategies; from efficacy of protective barriers; air purifiers; materials and balance between filtration and seal and flow diversion. In addition, we have also conducted a range of studies of indoor environmental conditions linked to cases of COVID-19 to link the epidemiological data to indoor environmental conditions that would govern persistence and mixing of indoor airborne contaminants. Finally, we have also developed novel measurement modalities that are integrated and precise to provide complementary and high precision measurements of airborne contaminants in conjunction with air turbulent mixing conditions, which will continue to enable further studies of exposure; mixing, or lack of, indoors; and help further guide mitigation strategies for reduction of local exposure from aerosols and airborne contaminant sources.
